I didn't know that you weren't stuck with whatever it landed on anymore, so I played it safe and chose my flavor. Now I know for next time...
author: Torie Y.

description:
I've been here twice...the first time was 10 years ago (when I was teen) & my second time was a few weeks ago. The ice cream is GOOD. They have a lot of different flavors & if you can't choose - just spin the wheel! 

What I like most about Polly Ann Ice Cream is that they're open late for my after dinner ice cream cravings.
author: Michelle F.

description:
I think this place is so cute. Their ice cream is so creamy too. 

I would def come back here. I would do the spin the wheel thing but I don't like durian, soooo I passed and got my usual ;]

anyways, overall the lady is friendly, their service is good, and their ice cream is too. 

happy eating! :)
author: Liberty C.

description:
ohhhhhh man ice cream...another weakness of mine.

Polly Ann's ice cream kills baskin robins', ben and jerry's, and cold stone's ice cream!   Every flavor i've tried..pineapple & coconut, pineapple & strawberry, mint chocolate chip, green tea, lychee....(yah i eat a lotta ice cream) i could REALLLY taste the flavor. MmMM they also give you free samples so u can make sure it meets your taste buds.  The prices are also really good too..i get a child size..looks small, but def. fills my tummy!
author: Kristen T.

description: This place is one-of-a-kind. They have a unique blend of ice cream flavors and they were extremely good. Despite not being able to choose the flavors I wanted after being peer pressured to spin the wheel twice, both flavors I got, however, were delicious. Do try their tea flavored ones and the one with cookie dough. Those are my top two favorite flavors from there.
author: Annie S.

description:
I've been coming to Polly Ann's since i was 2 years old, and i still come back for more. I don't recommend their random flavors like dragon or bubble gum because it's not to my likings but if you're a dare devil give it a try or spin the big wheel. you might get a free cone!

I LOVE Polly Ann's green tea, coffee brownie, mango and taro flavored ice creams.  oh yea! come with your doggy and they can get a free cone too!
author: Jessica T.

description:
Polly Ann's is a necesity for the few sweltering heat waves we get every year in the sunset. Two things have stood out in the past for me: the giant spinning wheel of indecision, and the durian ice cream I keep tricking people into trying (think kerosene flavor). 

This summer, what has stood out for me more than anything at Polly Ann's is the SOFT SERVE. Nothing beats the heat better than a vanilla chocolate swirl stacked ontop of a plain cone. 

I place Polly Ann's just below Mitchell's as far as favorites go. Truly unique/classic flavors, one of the best original ice cream shacks in San Francisco.
author: Asa S.

description:
I love the asian flavors at this place! Of the flavor's I tried, my favorites are honey dew, watermelon, and lychee. Not everything is made equal here, so definitely try the flavors before ordering. I'm giving it this place five stars based on the asian flavors only.

The jasmine tea was also good, but had a very strong tea aftertaste. I DID not like the green tea ice cream here, so definitely try it before you order it. I also tried sesame which was a little too nutty for me. The oreo cookie was unmemorable.

Definitely go here if you want asian flavored ice cream! Also beware of the hot fudge here...we got a banana split, and the hot fudge had the consistency and texture of snot...it was NOT pleasant to eat, and we mostly ate around it.
author: Cindy C.

description:
* y u m m y *  

Plain and simple, the best ice cream parlor in the Sunset. 

My favorite flavors are Lychee, Taro and Strawberry.  I have yet to try the Wheel of flavors, but I'm satisfied with my favorites, I have no real need for trying something new yet.  

I absolutely love Polly Ann's pre packaged ice creams for to go.  I recently bought a big huge tub of Lychee and Taro.  Mixing the two together at home is oh so yummy, a great combo together.  What I love most though, is the fact that no matter how long the ice cream is  sitting in your freezer, it never seems to get HARD.  Here, the ice cream is just as creamy and soft as if you ordered it right out of the actual shop.  I hate when I buy supermarket bought ice cream like Dryers, and after a few weeks in the freezer, it's so damn hard, you can barely scoop it out. This is NEVER the case at Polly Ann.  

I have my own personal Polly Ann right in my kitchen...Perfect!
author: Cass J.

description: Polly Ann you disappoint me. I've been here so many time every time I'm back home, but you keep failing me. I tried to give you the benefit of the doubt, but you just didn't cut it. My favorites are always the taro, jasmine, and green tea. This time, for some reason, your green tea looked brown and tasted like chocolate which reminded me of that article that I read about on how ice cream stores attempt to mix old chocolate ice cream with the mixture in order to save money or whatever. Your Jasmine is starting to downgrade too, not as flavorful as before. I am truly disappointed. It will be a while until I bring up the courage to try you out again. Hopefully, by that time, you'll be ready!
author: Vanna C.

description: This is one of the gem's of the Sunset neighborhood. Lots of good ice cream and GREAT customer service. They have a great selection of ice cream with over 20 flavors, including unusual selections like jasmine and durian.  My partner loves the lychee. They also do the classics, like mint, chocolate, and hazelnut quite well. There is a "wheel-of-fortune" for ice cream on the wall behind the counter, and on my first spin I won a free ice cream of my choice.  This shop is open later than other ice cream and Froyo shops, which is great for late night cravings. But what really makes this place great is the customer service.  I have always been helped by Chris, who I absolutely love. Seriously, this guy is great-the pinnacle of customer service IMO. He is always super friendly and patient with my (sometimes extreme) indecisiveness. He remembers me and my partner every time we come in and is genuinely happy to see us.  I have actually been meaning to write this review for a while. Every time I walk out of that place, I am super stoked about it.  This is one of the places that make the sunset a great neighborhood.
author: Stacy M.

description:
They have a lot of flavors at Polly Ann's, and all of them look pretty appetizing, which can lead to a lot of sampling and hard rumination.  To help break the gridlock of deliberation, there is a giant wheel on the back wall that looks like something out of a one-off gameshow.  Along the edge of the gargantuan wheel are numbers that correspond to the various flavor offerings.  Whatever number the pointer lands on, that's the flavor you get.

Notice: The Durian flavor doesn't appear on the wheel.

"Hmm.  I like durian" I thought.  "Maybe this could be good."  And I was right!  It WAS good!  But it didn't have the super pungent flavor that I expect fresh (well, "fresh" as any freeze dryed Thai-import) durian to have.  It also lacked that stringiness of durian, but the dairy helped to create that custard sensation that the fruit gives.  Overall, I was happy with it.

The funny part is that they keep the durian flavor waaaay in the back in one of those flip top freezers you see in old people's garages.  Its a little sad that they have this "separate but equal" policy for my beloved durian, but I guess that's the way it has to be.
author: Thomas M.

description:
Oh my gosh this place is the wheel of fortune of ice creams!  It's like a creative version of Baskin Robbins but way better.

They have a wheel for all the indecisive people that can decide for you because they have like 40 something flavor or something ridiculous.

My boyfriend and I shared a banana split with three different flavors of ice cream that I really don't remember because we devoured it too fast!  All week I couldn't stop thinking about it and we would joke about going even after we had already had dessert.

I will be back to visit as soon as I'm back in SF!
author: Elaine K.

description:
This place makes me want to have my own ice cream maker!!
I came here with a friend to explore SF. It's located fairly close to golden gate park, and there are plenty of street parking (we went on a weekday morning, so that might make a difference too! I was really surprised at how wide the streets are and how nice the building looks, since all the SF places I've been to are small, crowded, and... older looking. anyway, onto the ice cream!
We got a double scoop of Taro and Straw Rocky Road. I really enjoyed Both of the flavors. Taro had a right level of sweetness and even small chunks of taro, so I fell in love with it right away. The strawberry rocky road was really good as well. I personally LOVE chocolate rocky road, so the twist of having strawberry instead of chocolate was surprisingly delicious. It's strawberry ice cream (reminds me of my favorite childhood ice cream) with chunks of marshmallow and walnuts. Yums!

Be warned that there are over 40 flavors in the store, so it took USA few minutes to decide on the flavor. 2 scoops was around $5.
author: Melody Y.

description:
J, S and I ventured out in the cold last night in search for some 31 cents Baskin Robbin scoops.  We arrived at the Sloat location at 9:04 p.m., only to be told they were closed.

**SAD FACE**

Polly Ann to the rescue!  SPIN THE WHEEL!  SPIN THE WHEEL!

OK, so we zoomed back to Polly Ann and spun the giant wheel.  None of us got the free slot, but we were all lucky enough to have good flavors to choose from.

J ended up with lychee, S with chocolate brownie, and I chose mango in a sugar cone.  $2.75/scoop, definitely much steeper than we had anticipated.  That's almost 9 BR scoops!  Double sad face.

Whoo sugar high before bedtime!

Their fountain drinks have strange names.  It suckered J and S into ordering a large of Purple Dragon and and Suicide.  I had a taste of each and wanted to spit it back out.  Soda after ice cream = big no no.

The place is clean, parking isn't a hassle, and the ice cream girl seemed nice.  What's not to like?
author: Jenny L.

description:
Spin za Will!! This little shop is so cute with after school candies, drinks, and ice cream. They even serve snacks like hot dogs, chips, and such!

Me and my fiancé came here for the first time after grubbin' on some Toyose up the street. If you spin the wheel (hopefully you get the free one on which any flavor is of no cost), you have the option of choosing the number before or after which makes the experience less nerve racking! My favs are taro and rainbow sherbet (which tastes like the flinstones push ups)! I tried the coconut and coffee&caramel recently and both were good as well! My opinion is you can't go wrong with any flavor.
author: Rachel M.

description:
It ain't what it used to be. I haven't really liked Polly Ann ever since they remodeled. The ice cream here isn't creamy and smooth the way I like it -- it's chunky and icy. And yeah, they have a huge wall of flavors, but I'm not the daring type. 

I'd much rather go to Marco Polo if I'm in the sunset.
author: M B.

description:
Afraid I have to give them a low rating because they didn't have ANYTHING in the store I could taste or eat.  It's always disappointing to go to a place that boasts so much but forgets to serve people with heatlh issues.  In my case, I wanted to see at least one NO SUGAR ADDED FLAVOR to try.

You see in Europe and all good ice cream or gelato shop at least one if not several No Sugar Added Flavors - even the chain like Baskin Robins & Cold Stone Creamery.

In their favor - my family friends that I visited there with really liked their ice cream and the Green Tea was apparently the best ever had.
author: Rebecca H.

description:
I remember when polly ann's frosty was 50cents and a single scoop a dollar! ahh the good ole days!! Now a single is 2.50 and a frosty 1.50
;T

my favorite is the original mint chocolate chip! recently i was in the neighborhood and felt daring. I tried the star wars out of curiosity with my bf. Mint ice cream and marshmallows, who would of thought. mmm yummy! 

I love the gold bordered black sign that greets ice-cream lovers at the counter "In God we trust, Cash Only" cracks me up and the other quotes/sayings on the walls. 

I don't think doggies are welcomed in PA anymore. Do they still give out doggie cones??
author: Fat C.

description:
Adorable little ice cream shop! They have 48 delectable flavors, and if you can't decide, you can spin the wheel! Quirky, fun, and oh so delicious! Butter pecan and pistachio almond are two of my favorites - if you like a something on the not to sweet side. 

You may have to wait in line, but it is so worth it for the freshly made ice cream treats.
author: Jen M.

description:
Spin spin spin the wheel, if you're lucky, you get your ice-cream, FOR FREE.

Anyways. I love their green tea and jasmine tea ice-cream. The other flavors are good too, maybe I just have a thing for tea flavored ice-creams. 

BUT SERIOUSLY. You can't go wrong with green tea.
author: Tina C.

description:
Like eggettes, I was around polly anns even more! I've had plenty of family that worked here as well. I was around spending every bit of my allowance on bomberman candy, sour belts, and sugar straws! Their banana split, green tea/gummy bear ice cream, and purple dragon soda. Yeah, I remember everything clearly. I also remember it being better.

Now people may think its because I'm much older now and my taste buds have matured. When I first discovered Yelp, I was shocked to see a 4 star rating. The old store had much friendlier workers. Although it was much much smaller, it made everything more cozy, inviting, and inclusive. Now it feels awkward, abnormal, and too clean. Everything was piled up before, giving off the vibe of an "old" ice cream parlor. Their ice cream consistency has stayed the same. They have made everything more sanitary, which is a great thing, but I missed the individual bulk candies everything used to come in. Now everything is wrapped up and much more expensive than Safeway or another old liquor store. Some of the workers seem miserable and not too great. I mean don't get me wrong, I occasionally run into some of the veteran workers who clearly remember and greet me. I LOVE EM. But some of the newer people are a little.. misfitted? I feel weird and scared walking in.

Prices have slightly raised and portions have also slightly declined. They accept card now, which is a definite plus. Wish they would open later though..

I guess at the end of the day, my conclusion is.. I miss the old polly anns.
author: Wendy X.

description:
When my friend said she wanted to get ice cream on a Sunday night I wondered what ice cream shop could be open at that hour?? 

Polly Ann is.

Lots of ice cream options but a little overwhelming, they've got a good thing going on by offering ice cream flavors like lychee, red bean, and green tea that you can't find at most other ice cream shops. Make sure you've got cash though this place won't take cards.
author: Liz S.

description:
Ice cream was off the....

After much time deciding which flavor to eat...i ended up picking the durian flavor and my husband choose the Lychee flavor.

My husband's had the supermarket store version, but had never had the one from the actual parlor. According to him, it's all the same...just less flavors available at the supermarkets...way less. I do recall now, though vaguely, of him telling me about and showing me this ice cream in the supermarket. (i have selective hearing AND memory, so I missed out on it for many months...until i finally had the chance to make it here!)

The lady there was not very friendly. Hence why i only gave Pollyann 4 stars and not 5!!

I'd go back again because the ice cream was hella good, but service...not so great.
author: Alicia L.

description:
I had the banana rocky road and honey dew melon.  The banana flavor was pretty good, but i've had better banana ice cream.  The honey dew was freaking awesome.  I'd really really recommend it, it's somehow a refreshing ice cream flavor.

I prefer this place over Bi-Rite and Humphrey Slocombe.  The ice cream isn't as heavy, making it easier to eat and not feel like you just ate a meal.
author: Lawrence C.

description: Not the same.....and not because they moved but because all the huge candy jars and the smell of hotdogs and nachos are gone. The homey feel is no longer. The ice cream tasted weird. I was so disappointed. This was a favorite spot as a youngin and my dad loved it too. It was our "thing". I'm sad ;(
author: Sophie P.

description:
I usually get the half-gallon sized container to take home from here. I love that you can mix the flavors, I get half Honeydew and half Green Tea every time. So good! 

They also have a freezer on the side that sells their signature Polly Ann popsicles in a box of 4-6. The Red Bean ones are pretty good.
author: Nancy L.

description:
I love Polly Ann's Ice Cream! 

I used to come here almost everyday after work in the summers back when I was working in Stonestown and didnt care about my waistline. 

I love their giant wheel, its so funny! (really you arent FORCED to buy the ice cream u land on but you might as well since you have 4 options anyway!) 

They have a giant selection, and the service is always prompt and friendly! Yay for PollyAnns!
author: Amy S.

description:
This is my 2nd favorite Ice Cream place! First has to be hands down Mitchells Ice Cream! 

Whenever I come here, I ALWAYS spin the wheel. Just because 1) I get a chance to get a free ice cream and 2) I like trying new flavors. They have some really good flavors on the wheel, and some really how should I say this? ... different flavors such as Durian flavor and Licorice flavor! ha but its all good! 

Definitely come here if your in the area. Really residential but perfect on a sunny day in San Francisco, in the sunset district!
author: Daniel S.

description: I like the variety of flavors they have here, can't get more anywhere else! It didn't help that the first scoop my friend ever recommended me here was durian - and I had no idea what durian was at the time. Good thing I went again..had a much better experience : ]
author: Cindy S.

description:
Came back recently with the dog.  They gave him a small little bit of vanilla ice cream on a little cone.  He loved it.

Woof!  -- this means Thanks!  in dog.
author: Winnie C.

description:
Our soccer coach used to take us here after games if we won (which was a lot!). Before today, I hadn't been to Polly Ann's in forever - and I was pumped. 

Sadly, now I'm disappointed and have probably ruined a wonderful childhood memory. I miss the old hand-painted signs and general warmth of the old store. This new interior is cold and uninviting. As I walked in, I reminded myself that the ice cream obviously speaks for itself and didn't need all of my old memories to make it delicious. 

Boy, was I wrong :( 

I figured my taste buds have upgraded since 8th grade Bubblegum ice cream, so I opted for the the Chocolate Brownie instead. Bluck! Talk about tasteless - I literally felt just coldness in my mouth. There was no chocolately deliciousness and barely any brownies. 

I'm definitely not coming back :(
author: Jennifer L.

description:
It's alright.
I didn't know what to order and I wasn't sure what do with the wheel. stupid me I decided to spin the wheel not knowing wherever it landed that's what you get. Since I didn't want the Irish cream whiskey I told the lady no! She was nice enough to say ok what do you want then... I chose kooky monster or whatever and the bf chose caramel cookie dough which was too sweet.

Total: $6 even
+1 for the nice lady
+2 I actually liked my ice cream.
author: Anna P.

description: Polly Ann's is literally two blocks down from my church on Noriega, so my friends and i and other church go-ers (including the young adults) are frequent customers. although it's a small place with few seats, the staff is friendly, and the ice cream is awesome and comes in a variety, unconventional flavors (ex. durian). sometimes i'll have a craving and make the 20-minute drive (on a non-Sunday) just to stop by. but if you're not as wacky as me, you can find their ice cream at Asian supermarkets in the frozen section (ex. Ranch 99, Manila, Pacific Super). they also have candy, hot dogs, milkshakes and other items besides ice cream at the shop. they give big scoops for the price and have a long list of flavors. can't decide? spin the wheel and get a chance to win a free scoop (and trust me, it's not rigged; i've landed on it more than once!).
author: Mike C.

description:
I've been wanting to try Polly Ann's for so long and finally got my chance on VDay.  From the funny quotes on the walls to all the cool flavor names you can choose from and even a giant wheel for you indecisive people (like my boyfriend) - this place is truly unique!  
I got the green tea ice cream...loves it!  I gotsta come back for more!
author: jesiree b.

description:
3.75 stars I'd say...

Best CLASSIC green tea ice cream I've had in the city! 

It's just a good place for classic ice cream. It's not like Birite's creativity or interesting flavors or like Mitchell's exactly, but it's a classic type of ice cream in a nice residential part of SF.
author: Eryn K.

description: Hella good!! Eating their ice cream is hella addicting!! Like a person addicted to crack!!! Mint Chocolate Chip, Cookies and Cream, and Pistachio with a waffle cone!!! (not all at once, I've tried each flavor on a cone) :D
author: Tiffany T.

description:
Where else can you get an ice cream that's called "Bumpy Freeway?" I mean, really, it's Rocky Road (ha!) but it tastes just that much better with the spiffy name.

My favorite is the Jasmine Tea. It's incredibly fragrant, and although it's kind of a nasty color... oh wait, there IS no nasty color for ice cream. It's just great.

If you go when it's not crowded, they'll give you endless samples if you're nice :) Sabra is my second favorite - how can you go wrong with chocolate orange ice cream?

Seriously, this is my new favorite ice cream shop in the world. It just might be yours as well.
author: Tori S.

description: love their ice cream............so soft and creamy. my favorites are the mango, green tea, cookies and cream and their strawberry. even if u buy it in the containers the ice cream still tastes just as fresh. one of my favorite places to go for ice cream esp on tuesdays when it has a special for buying the ice cream in the tubs! =)
author: Stella J.

description:
Horrible.  It's over-rated!  I like box ice cream from Safeway better!

Pro: Lots of choices and there's a cool wheel.

Con: It's over-rated, enough said.
author: Anh T.

description:
After a long day, sometimes I need a little extra kick in the pants to get the dog out for her evening stroll. Polly Ann's provides both a kick in the ass and junk to the trunk, not to mention an insuperable selection of poison from which to pick. 31 Flavors cowers in inadequacy. Sesame and lychee are among my favorites, and while I tried the durian root on a dare, really did not find it all that horrible. They also make a mean ice cream sunday with all the fixings, and carry soft serve ice cream, frozen bananas, and a vast array of candy. They even sell their ice cream by the pint, if you're not as lucky as I am to live within walking distance.

However, as Polly Ann's is geared more towards the to-go customer, do not expect elaborate porcelain dishes or plentiful seating. The seating is in fact extremely limited. This weekend I had to break up a fight between my boyfriend's 2 year old and some other sugar crazed child over the one precious remaining stool. He had that same glare in his eyes that I get when some poor unknowing soul comes in between me and a cab. Also, apparently in another effort to encourage customers to indulge at home, they keep all their napkins behind the counter! So be sure to ask for a big handful if you plan to eat in house and keep your mess in check.

Also, for the rest of you dog lovers out there, Polly Ann's is very dog friendly. Don't be shy to bring your pal inside while you order, they even have doggy cones so they don't feel left out! Very appreciated.
author: Taylor E.

description: Solid Asian flavors: green tea, black sesame, red bean, etc. So many choices. "SPIN THE WHEEL." Bumpy Freeway? Rocky Road, duh. Durian's locked up in the back.
author: Basile K.

description:
TOTALLY ONO! 

I heart Polly Ann's! The wall of flavors is a little overwhelming at first, but the staff is accomodating, quick and friendly...and always willing to provide an explanation of the flavors (uh...what's "Star Wars"? - simple, it's mint chip with colored marshmallows, of course!).

I wasn't all that daring (no Bumpy Highway for me), I finally decided on the Strawberry Mango ice cream. YUMMY. Others in with me got flavors like: Sabra (chocolate orange), cookie dough, and mint chip (plain, no Star Wars).

So much ice cream...so little time. 5 shakas, I'll be back...fo'sho!
author: Dawn S.

description:
I'm sad to say I've never been here, but..

I.LOVE.THEIR.ICE.CREAM.

I'm a green tea ice cream fiend. Because of this, it's been a journey to find the perfect green tea ice cream.. especially when Dreyer's doesn't really sell it too often in grocery stores. For a long time, it was either Dreyer's green tea ice cream or fork up $4 for a small ass scoop from a Japanese restaurant.

No, thanks.

Then years ago, Magnolia, the beloved Filipino ice cream manufacturer -- who made yummy flavors like lanka/jack fruit, ube, and macapuno/young coconut -- came up with green tea! You better believe that ish was put in the cart with the quickness!

I got home. Opened that big tub of green tea goodness and dug in!!!!!!!!!!

Unfortunately.. it sucked. Nothing compared to the Dreyer's version. It was creamy, but other than that.. blllehck.

Then one day I came across Polly Ann. I found it in the Marina Asian grocery store. Having been burned before, I thought.. "Hmph..... what else is there to lose except $4?" (Actually nothing, because my dad paid for it hehehe) 

Expecting nothing, I put it in the freezer and forgot it for a few days. 

Then came one of those days when girls just crave stuff for no reason.. a la Monica.. "it's just one of dem days"-type 'o things.

With a heaping bowl, I took a spoonful and immediately found myself in awe! So creamy! Yummy! Green Tea-y!!! I can't imagine how many tubs I've gone through, but it's a lot! Even though the price has slowly risen, I still buy it!

Really, nothing compares.. Not Maeda-en, not the Safeway Premium Brand (it's basically green colored vanilla)..

Polly Ann all the way :)
author: Christina Y.

description: Good Asian ice cream flavors. I especially enjoyed their lychee. I'd go elsewhere though for the more traditional ice cream flavors. My bf and I were not impressed with their oreo cookie or strawberry (tasted artificial). Also, the quality of the ice cream was not as great as Bi-Rite or Humphry Slocombe- too dense and not as rich. They have DOGGIE CONES though! A little soft-serve ice cream in a mini cone to give to your dog. Absolutely adorable. Our dog loved it.
author: Sophia B.

description: Recommended by a friend and yes, I was not disappointed! Polly Anns have unique flavors and it was pretty cool that they had a "spin the wheel if u cant decide which flavor to choose" kind of deal. They are also very generous to those who have dogs because they will give out complimentary dog size ice cream cones! I will most definitely come back because I fell in love with their jasmine ice cream!
author: Ella A.

description: This review is only for their durian ice cream: It is not authentic - smells artificial and looks artificial. The place looks nice though.
author: July N.

description:
Batman.

That was the first flavor I ever tried at Polly Ann's. It was blueberry ice cream with yellow marshmellows (banana flavored?), created in honor of the movie that was coming out at the time (the Keaton/Nicholson version). That fact: 1. dates me and 2. gives you a pretty good idea of the longevity of this establishment. 

That said, I believe that quality ice cream in a world where people buy gifts, underwear and lunch online, to get out and drive to a place to enjoy a sweet outing is something that should be savored.

This place was in a smaller nook a little further up the block when I started going. The folkloric signs were there then and there was a lot more impetus to change flavors on a regular basis. The ice cream wheel of fortune that I've never bothered to use was there as well. 

I am wistful: the only times I've been have been with friends. I've been with the same friends from high school in recent years, now with children and careers. I've been with that lactose-intolerant friend who risked an immediate bathroom run to try a scoop of what she would call "yummage" forever after. 

It's important to rate a place for its food goodness but I believe it to be valid if you can rate it for its tradition, too. I am fond of the unusual and Polly Ann's is off the beaten path in terms of flavors and location (near St. Ignatius). 

When I come back to the City by the Bay, this is always one of the stops I make. It always reminds me that some things never change. 

Here, here!
author: Fumiko N.

description:
Ive only been here once and the ice cream here already amazes me! i ordered the jasmine tea ice cream i think thats what it called! My friend said it tastes like flower and OMG it definetly does!!! their flavors are very consistent!! and the price are reasonable. Definitely coming back here for some more ice cream hahahaz, especially when i have practice a block away lolz!!
    Try the thai tea Popsicle the ones that are in the fridge that comes in boxes theyy taste just like thai tea it is SUPER DAMN YUMMY!! and it was a buck for 4 popsicles HOLY CRAPZ!! definitely come and try this place out =]
author: Alice C.

description: I love going to Polly Ann's to spin the wheel.. makes it easier to try something new.  my favorites - ube, green tea, earl grey, bumpy freeway (rocky road) and star wars (vanilla with marshmellows).
author: golf g.

description: OMG they have 50 flavors.BUT they have cup noodles, candy, drinks, even to go ice creams.YOU MUST GO THERE!!!!!! But after school the is a lot of Giannini students
author: Victoria L.

description:
Spin the Wheel of "Joy" on those days you just don't know
what flavor ice cream brings a big smile across your face =)

This neighborhood ice cream store has served locals for at least
20 years that I know of, but since then it has relocated and remodeled to look clean
and spacious.  Now there are good amount of seats now for locals,
who want to hang out.  Otherwise, you can buy your pints/tubs to-go!

My favorites are COCONUT, BLACK SESAME, MANGO, 
GREEN TEA, EXPRESSO, RED BEAN
 and LYCHEE.

Pluses:
+ Lots more flavors than Baskin-Robbins.
+ When you spin the wheel, you have a chance to win a FREE ice cream.
OK you math whizzes, try to figure out the probability of winning.
+ A FREE doggy cone when you leave your dog outside the store.
+ Place to sit.
+ Friendly and helpful staff.

Minuses:
- Drats.  Closes at 10pm.
- Credit cards need a minimum of $5.
- Hard to find parking during busy hours.

Tips:
* Do not go around 3pm when middle school kids line up.
* Root beer float does not taste that good.
* Some supermarkets carry their pints, if you do not want to drive so far.
* Stay away from vegetable flavor.
author: CT L.

description: The best green tea ice cream I've ever had!!  I actually discovered this ice cream after eating at Mom's Shabu Shabu House where they served us the green tea ice cream for dessert, and I later found out via Yelp reviews that this delicious ice cream was from Polly Ann's.  I've never had better green tea ice cream before, it's super creamy and has a pretty distinct green tea taste to it.  Went to Polly Ann's to buy a whole tub of it!  Could eat this everyday (if it weren't for the high fat calorie content...)!!
author: Lauren S.

description:
Stopped by here for a snack, but got caught in line after a kid's soccer match let out.  Tried the caramel cookie dough in a cone and it was great!  I haven't kept up with my asian ice cream, but Polly Ann's is the famous brand you buy in the supermarket.  They had a plethora of flavors and I can't wait to come back.

Street parking is available and didn't seem overly packed.
author: Henry L.

description:
I really liked the unique flavors of ice cream, not the best, but if you are adventurous I recommend spinning the wheel.

If not, by far they make the BEST GREEN TEA ice cream. Words cannot describe how good it is. Every time I crave Green Tea Ice Cream I automatically think of this amazing place.

Although, if you do go at after school hours such as 3-5 ish on weekdays you do run into younger children who could be quite rude and obnoxious. One instance, kids were taking up most of the space inside and they were not even eating any ice cream.
author: Danielle B.

description:
My BF use to always take me here for icecream 3 years ago when we were first "dating"- such a smart guy, no wonder we're still together! 

Cute, clean icecream store with seats by the windows and a variety of flavors to choose from. I usually get strawberry on a waffle cone- double scoop, of course :P
author: M W.

description: A Quaint neighborhoody Ice Cream Shop. I love walking down Ocean Beach and then coming here to get ice cream. The girls who work there are super sweet so please be patient if there is a line out the door. Most of the time customers can't decide out of the 50 flavors. If you are daring, spin the wheel and you will be stuck with whatever flavor it lands on. But if you are like me, its only to take a minute or two...or 10 to decide. I am only adventurous enough to try the Green Tea, which tastes surprisingly like real tea--a little bitter but pretty darn good. Its ice cream so there are no bells or whistles but its all about nostalgia. I love that there are cute little places like this.
author: Ramany And Michael K.

description:
I've boycotted Polly Ann ever since I spun the flavor misfortune wheel and I was handed a cone of "Bubble Gum" ice cream loaded with gumballs.

It was Thee Worst Flavor I ever had. Licking ice cream and chewing a growing wad of gum at the same time is just too much multitasking. Chewing gum hardens when mixed with cold. Hellooo?  (Tip: spit the gumballs into a small baggy and give it away as a treat). 

Years later--having made peace with Polly--the Kooky Dough was more to my liking. Good place to hit up after a day at the beach or playing ball in the Avenues. 

* * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * 
What gets me exciTED, in order:

  1.  MITCHELL'S ICE CREAM
  2.  The Old San Francisco Creamery (Walnut Creek)
  3.  Ben & Jerry's
  4.  Coldstone Creamery
  5.  Bi-Rite Creamery
  6.  Fenton's (Piedmont Ave.)
  7.  Swenson's
  8.  Polly Ann (SF Sunset)
  9.  Ici Ice Cream (College Ave.)
10.  Baskin Robbins
author: Teddy B.

description:
Spin the wheel!
Round and round she goes...where she stops nobody knows. 
Will it be lychee?  Will it be free?  Will it be just plain ol green tea?
Ooooh lookie!!!  Its Turkish coffee!
Yippee!!
author: Lauren F.

description:
Yum Yum! We ordered a dessert at Sanmi last night and we fell in love with the Black Sesame Ice Cream ... so we had to ask where they got it from! ^)^ The owner told us and we were on a hunt/mission to find this place....it's really really really far away from where we are... almost on the exact opposite side.

So after dinner we drove out looking for this place so that we can pick up tubs of ice cream for home.  After realizing how far it was... my sister decided that she is going to stock up because she doesn't want to drive this far again.  lol I was the first in the store and I saw the abundant choices to choose from... so what else can I do but ask for samples! ^_^ 

They ran out of Durian, but I found it in the freezer so I bought a huge tub blindly to try.  I bought 5 tubs tonight... if you can imagine.. 

1 Durian
1 Black Sesame
1 Green Tea
1 Mango 
1 Lychee

Let's just say we will be eating ice cream for a LOOOOONG time.  The wheel is cute to help make up your mind.  Instead I just kept trying all the flavors I was thinking about or what I might want to have.  The people working there were Chinese and it was quite funny because they apparently didn't think I was??? I walked in and they greeted me and then I heard them speak in Mandarin about how come no hot guys come... I said back in Mandarin... "where's the hot guy?"  They were taken aback and were surprised... I guess I could have remained incognito and listened to their conversations without them knowing but I rather shock ppl that HELLO I am Asian.  O=)

They have a good consistency for their ice cream and sorbets.  The flavors range from exotic fruits, teas, and more.  This is a very Asian flavored store so a lot of their fruit flavors have that flowery oomph in the taste.  I ended up tasting a ton of flavors but decided on the 5 mentioned above.  The durian ice cream ended up being not what I thought it to be.  I don't think it's strong enough in flavor and in taste, but it definitely has the funk! Warning... Durian is really for those who have had it, don't try it hear unless you know what it is.

I thought the mango had a nice flavor with the flowery touch and the lychee was only so-so.  The best is still the black sesame and it's just as good as when we had it at Sanmi.  I think that will be the first tub to run out! O=9

The pre-packed ice creams sold there are super cheap compared to getting scoops or having them pack it for you fresh.  I think they are a great deal.  For the 4 tubs and 1 smaller tub I only paid $32 and I gave them a tip for letting me try the ice cream to find which one I want.  ^_^
author: Kat L.

description:
4.5 stars

I used to LOVE coming here as a kid. My grade school would take us here after fieldtrips. We'd all get the soft serve cone. I remember being too short to see over the counter, and so there were these little steps by the door that us little kids could prop ourselves up on to see all the action. My mom would also take us here after doing the shopping at the korean market...The old location was great. Lots of memories....

Fast forward 20 years, now Polly Ann's is at a new location, down the street and on the cornor, next to a bright new Eggettes, no more Korean market there :( , and when did these new condos come in?

The ice cream is still good. The place is much bigger and brighter now. They still got the wheel, and our friend got a free cone that night after a lucky spin. 

Man! things sure do change! I don't really like change. I really try to resist it or hide from it. Maybe that's why it took me so long to make my way back around here again. 

I would have given 5 stars, if they would have kept it real and lived it up in the old hole in the wall location...that's just me...
author: Caroline C.

description:
I can't believe it's taken me this long to write a review of Polly Ann's.

Long before I lived in San Francisco, I used to look forward to visiting my brother because he lived within a few blocks of this place.  When it was closed for more than a year, I was really sad because I thought it would never return.  When it did reopen, I wasn't too impressed by the new building itself, but much of the charm remained.

So you probably want me to talk about the ice cream and how good it is.  It is good, but I'm going to talk about the wheel instead.

When you go to Polly Ann's, you should ask for the wheel.  When you do, the worker will turn around nonchalantly and spin the wheel.  While it's spinning, he or she will not seem very interested in where it lands.  That's part of their job; I've spun the wheel dozens of times, and never has an employee been interested.

In the old days, the wheel had nails in between each section so that it was clear which number you had landed on.  The nails are gone, so it's often a judgment call.  That's unfortunate, because if you're a purist, and you should be, you would insist on getting the flavor it landed on.  Even if you don't like it.  I had the distinct misfortune of the wheel landing on durian once, so I had to deal with gas-breath for two days.  But I don't regret it.  I've also won free ice cream twice with the wheel, so that one unfortunate experience was worth it.  Oh, and they've removed durian from the wheel rotation, so you don't have to worry about spinning anymore.

The weird sayings aren't as fitting in the new interior, but they're pretty cool in a corny way.
author: John S.

description:
My doggie and I LOVE this place!

Good homemade, neighborhood ice cream with lots of variety and decent prices.

Last time I came with the BF and doggy and we were ALL left satisfied.  Upon paying for our ice cream the server asked if we wanted a "doggy cone."  I was very pleasantly surprised.  We all left happy and the doggy was the first to finish his doggy ice cream :)  Will definitely ALL come back for more!
author: J P.

description:
So many flavors to choose from!  What to get?  What to get????  SPIN THE WHEEL!!!!

I've actually spun the wheel a few times, and luckily didn't land on any weird flavors like durian......although I think I might have to try it some day.  You don't have to get the actual flavor you land on...you can choose from the two flavors next to it as well.  I still haven't landed on a free cone, but I'll just have to keep trying!

Whenever I walk in to Polly Ann's, I stand there, staring at the wall of flavors.  Hmmm...what to get today?  I always say I'll try something new, but I end up getting one of my favorites....taro, green tea, mango, pistachio almond or honeydew melon.

No matter how cold it is in the city, you'll always find a line at Polly Ann's....who could resist all those yummy flavors???  And don't forget about your four-legged friend!  They'll give him a doggie sized cone with soft serve ice cream.
author: Patra I.

description: Was there yesterday. Picked up some ice cream - 1/2 gallon of Mango and 1/2 gallon of Green Tea. Nothing but the best. My daughter had a Bubble Gum cup and she (8yo) said it one of the best if not THE BEST. Polly Ann ice creams are amazing...
author: Winglo A.

description: I always love coming to Polly Ann.  There's always parking right outside.  The shop is clean and bright, and the ice cream is YUM.  I recommend red bean flavor.
author: Anna K.

description:
A friend of mine had recommended Polly Ann Ice Cream in the Sunset.  Her family has been going where her son was a baby, who is now going to college.

Walking in I notice all the different flavors on the wall.  I especially notice the Wheel Of Fortune wheel in the center.  If you can't decide, you are welcome to spin the wheel.  Each slot on the wheel has a number that represents a flavor on the menu.  When you land on the number you have 3 options, the actual slot, the one to the left or the one to the right.  There are a couple of free ice cream slots if you are super lucky!

Since I am intrigued by a great marketing gimmick, I decide to go for the spin.  I land exactly on the jasmine tea - my other choices were red bean and chocolate chip which sounded good too.  Jasmine tea is a nice smooth flavor, and not to sweet.  Very good!

Also, they serve Durian ice cream.  I laugh when it is not part of the "wheel" selections, and they have to go to the back to serve it.   When my husband asked for Durian, she thought (or wanted to think) he asked "lemon" and he said no "Durian".   Always good to double check.

Thanks Polly Ann -- will always go back to try my luck at the wheel!!
author: Janet H.

description:
a neighborhood staple since forever ! I went to the jr. high a block away and some afternoons I would drop in for a small frosty -- cold creamy luscious pleasure in a wafer cup. Blue soda or a green dragon or a suicide (all flavors mixed together) were my other favs. they had a terrific sign: "our manager is Helen Wait. if you are unhappy or impatient, go to Helen Wait."  f-ing hilarious ! they closed for a while when the block was being renovated and I was purely heartbroken. they re-opened with a whole new look but kept most of its old-time charm. there's nothing quite like a mix (a half vanilla and half chocolate frosty) to bring back my childhood.

ps: the blueberry ice cream is delightful
author: Prima D.

description:
Polly Ann is an old time San Francisco creamery.  It has one of the best taro ice cream, and a number of unique flavors such as rum raisin, durian and "star wars."  

Yes, it's a very creative creamery.  I would highly recommend Polly Ann to anyone who loves ice cream.
author: Jeannine L.

description: Green tea ice cream is bomb here!!!
author: Anthony V.

description: Not even a hello as I walked in, just a blank kind of stare. Maybe not even that much, the employee was probably looking past me. There were a lot of flavors to choose from and it took me a really long time to decide. I would've appreciated a recommendation or something, but that's probably asking too much. I kept it simple with dutch chocolate. It was nothing special. I'd never go out of my way to come back here.
author: Tiffany P.

description:
I recently came here for the first time since they've moved locations on Noriega. The old shop was pretty danged small. 

Their new home is clean, bright, and is a pretty open space, complete with spinning wheel of ice cream flavors. You can ask the person behind the counter to spin it, and if it lands on a number, you can choose that corresponding flavor, or the two that are next to it on the wheel. If you are lucky enough for it to land on free, then I guess you get free ice cream. I don't know if you have to get the flavor that it lands on, but I don't think they enforce it that strictly. Do you really think they can FORCE you to order durian ice cream against your will? hahaha

They have a pretty good amount of flavors you can't find anywhere else. Jasmine Tea, Durian are the two that really vividly pop up in my mind, but they are always changing it up. 

The texture of the ice cream is very creamy and very soft. Personally I prefer Lappert's over in Sausillito more, as far as their coconut/pineapple flavor is concerned. 

but what i DOOOOOOO really really REALLY like is that they will dip your ice cream in chocolate to create that nice hard shell. i LOVE that. one extra star for just that. other wise i would have given them maybe 3 stars. 

The sundae's are kinda blah. It's a tiny plastic bowl container with two scoops of ice cream (of your choice) and two toppings of your choice, the bf chose drizzled chocolate fudge and strawberry jam stuff. He found it to be WAY to sweet, like so sweet where it kind of hurts your throat afterwards??? 

They charge an extra 50 cents for a waffle cone, but its not that big. Again... I kind of prefer Lappert's and bi-rite.
author: Irene C.

description:
Welcome to the WALL OF FLAVORS!  

I get excited just thinking about it...

I've been going to this ice cream parlor for almost 30 years.  I remember bringing a chum from out of town here decades ago, getting lost and randomly going up and down streets for literally HOURS.

"This looks familiar... I am sure it's down this street..." 

When I was a kid, all the signs were hand painted and had cutesy illustrations on them (honestly I find the new interior rather cold and sterile in comparison.)  I remember Rose was my favorite flavor (after my mom eliminated bubble gum from the list of potential choices...but that's a story for another time). I remember never wanting to spin the wheel in case I ended up with a vegetable flavor.( Blech!)

Polly Ann's is another one of those San Francisco traditions; a great place to add to your list of in-law schlepping landmarks.
author: Genevra P.

description: I didn't realize that I came here before until I was about to write a review for this place and saw that I already had one . I think I have really bad memory because I don't even recall ever having their ice cream . Anyways , I tried their sesame flavor recently and it was alright but I feel like the flavor wasn't rich enough . Will be back to try more flavors ...
author: Eileen L.

description:
The gift certificate I earned at the Yelp Cupcake Bake-Off has been burning a hole in my pocket, so we decided to make the trek out to the Sunset and check it out and spend my loot. 

Love the spin the wheel option, although I couldn't bring myself to let a wheel decide my flavor choice.

The kid behind the counter patiently gave us tastes of almost everything on the menu. Thanks for that!

I found that most of the flavors I tried didn't have a strong flavor, it was mostly masked by the creaminess of the butter fat. The pomegranate was more creamy than fruity, as was the mango, taro and several other fruit-based flavors. 

The macapuna was on par with Mitchell's and I would have ordered it if I hadn't just polished off a gallon of the Mitchell's version a few weeks back. 

I'm actually kind of glad that it wasn't the best ice cream ever because the outer Sunset location really isn't conducive to ice cream cravings for this East Bay gal.
author: Lee H.

description:
Nice sunny day @ the beach and venturing for some ice cream.  Hey look what we found, its Wheel of Fortune!!! Unfortunately Pat Sajak and Vanna White arent here but there's 'A Wall of Flavor' for good ice cream @ Polly Ann's. 
They have so many flavors that will make your head explode.  So to reduce the tension of picking which flavor to get, they a wheel for you to turn with all of the flavors labeled and a additional label that says 'free ice cream.'  This makes more tempting to spin the wheel for a chance @ a free scoop of ice cream.  
Unfortunately I did not spin the wheel but wound up with some good pistachio almond which was very good.  Next time I'll definitely spin the wheel and maybe get some free ice cream or else I have to buy a vowel. =/
author: Kris A.

description:
Back then when I was a student at A.P. Giannini, I used to come here every day after school to get my daily dose of their vanilla/chocolate frosty.

Back then when they were a hole in the wall.

I was so devastated when they closed down (along with Kukje Market... OMG, I loved their chicken, but that's another story) because they were having apartments built on top of their stores. 

I waited ever-so-patiently for a couple years... Okay, maybe not so patiently with my intense Polly Ann withdraws every time I passed by what used to be their store. Oh, how it ached my heart when I couldn't get my Polly Ann's ice cream! 

But if you can imagine how ecstatic I was when I found out when they reopened. 

They have tons of flavors. I love that they have lots of Asian flavors: sesame, green tea, taro, ube, ginseng, mango, lychee and DURIAN.. Yeah, that's right - I said durian. Did I ever mention that I love durian?

Oh honey, they even got nutella flavored ice cream! Gotta try that out!

The owner has the same last name as me, maybe we're related! More the reason to love this place!

I gotta support my local Sunset ice cream shop, only 6 blocks away from home.
author: Nance W.

description: Polly Ann, you need to stop making gazillion flavors and concentrate on perfecting your ice cream.
author: Bayarea K.

description:
Polly Anns? 
Eggettes?
Polly Anns?
Eggettes?
WHY DO THEY HAVE TO BE NEXT TO EACHOTHER!!! :(
(Eggettes always wins though, heehee)

In anycase, I'm in love with Polly Ann's Peach & Strawberry ice cream. I think it's the best since there are real strawberry chunks in them. 

I love their big wheel (with all their ice cream flavors on it) that they have but if you decide to spin it, you're mandated to get whatever it lands on. What happened to America, the land of FREEDOM?
author: Heidi C.

description:
The roulette wheel is risky, but I love it!! They let you choose one of three flavors it lands on, and if you're lucky enough, you may land on the FREE one as well! It's a bit of a drive for me, but the ice cream is YUMMY. Creamy. Green tea is good. Turkish coffee is good. I have many flavors to go through, and I love how Rocky Road is called Bumpy Freeway.  :p

They should have happier people working there. Come on, you're selling ice cream!
author: Tinna H.

description:
It's pretty good...a nice little local ice cream purveyor that churns out quality ice cream a cut above the 31 Flavors chain. However, I think Bi-Rite is better; then again, Bi-Rite is in a class all its own. Haagen-Dazs' rendition of the fruit flavors and Rum Raisin are a tad better than Polly's. The french vanilla lacks the richness of most of its peers, and the cookies and cream variations are just okay. 

BUT there is a silver lining: I'll tell you what you should bookmark this place for....distinctly Asian-influenced flavors: green tea (best I've ever had), white sesame, black sesame, taro, jasmine tea (niiiice), and uh...I'm sure I'm missing something else here. But you get the point.
author: Virg Y.

description:
Oh polly ann's all the memories I have of you!

I used to frequent this ice cream parlor when it was just a hole in the wall and I had to use a ledge on the side of the counter to actually see the flavors they had. 

Not only does this nifty ice cream store have a larger space now, but they have managed to still serve all their old crazy flavors (batman, star wars etc.) They also continue to carry the super stinky ice cream that is based off the tropical Durian fruit, which is not only  potent in smell but cures my time of the month cravings, which ads to my adoration for this quaint parlor that is the only place that carries my very odd fix. 

They also have other yummy flavors such as Taro and Red bean that are hard to find elsewhere.
author: Amina Z.

description:
This little ice cream place has everything you could want (in an ice cream store).  

First, it has a WHEEL to spin with numbers corresponding to their ice cream flavors.  If you haven't decided what to get they will spin the wheel for you.  This prevents unduly indecision paralysis for your most choice challenged friends.  You no longer are sentenced to wait as your *considerate* friend tastes each and every ice cream flavor 3x and compares them to other ice cream flavors as a line forms all the way to the beach.   The wheel thing is great.  

Second, their ice cream comes in flavors like *star wars* or *et* or at the bottom, hidden in the corner slightly is *durian*.  The great thing about the flavors are that beyond the 12 generic flavors you get other places (chocolate, vanilla, strawberry, *creative* vanilla with little vanilla beans in it or whatever...) their flavors seem to be a little more original (lychee, mango, taro, sesame, things you have to ask about) .  They have 3 types of cones, soft serve ice cream, sundaes, milkshake things and drinks, too.

If you have a dog, then every dog accompanied by a human gets a free ice cream cone if the person purchases a cone themselves.  So far it seems no one has obnoxiously pretended to get their dog a cone and *scored* the 2 for 1 dealio.  Hooray.

There really isn't a place to sit, so get ready to take it to go.
author: Gwen P.

description:
This is one of my all-time favorite ice cream shops.  Over 400 flavors! (about 50 in-store at any given time)

Strange and interesting flavors including:
-Black Liccorice
-Strawberry Oreo (my new favorite)
-Honeydew Melon
-Poppy Seed

They also have all the classics of course.  Their ice cream is really good and the prices are very reasonable.  

Plus they have THE WHEEL!  Spin the wheel and you have to get whatever flavor the wheel lands on, but if you are lucky you will land on one of the spots that gets you your ice cream for free!
author: Alex K.

description:
Over 40 flavors of great tasting, great quality ice cream in a pleasant, well run shop near the beach. 
Many Asian inspired flavors as well as the classics. I had the cookies and cream but I gave the Lychee a try and it was great as well. Candy, sodas, milkshakes, and other treats are available as well.
author: Yvette L.

description:
I LOVE this place. It was my first time here and it was love at first taste. They had green tea ice cream!!! My favorite. I always go to mitchell's for ice cream, but they don't have green tea. 
The green tea and mango ice cream is the bomb!!!
author: Vicki H.

description:
First of all, I've been to so many sushi restaurants that served Green tea Ice cream and none of them seem to match the taste I was looking for...until I had the Green tea ice cream at Sakana bune!

So, I asked the nice waitress what was the brand name of the Ice Cream and she said it's called Polly Ann. She also gave me directions to the place, for it was located in Noriega Street! AWESOME! 

So, I went there and bought myself 20 gallons...and I think I gained 145 lbs....

Depression is setting in...
author: Marc E.

description:
It was just okay. I had the Green Tea, and I've definitely have had better. I had little tastes of my friend's flavors, and they were just ok. Nothing Jumped out at me. And, there's no where to sit! Uber lame. They had a pretty big space, but no chairs or tables, or outdoor patio. 

Now, I would dock them a couple more stars, but luckily for them, I'm a huge dog lover. And they have tiny cute cones that they have for your dog! It was quite adorable!

Come here if you have a dog and want to treat them out. Don't come here if you're just a human and want ice cream.
author: Jon C.

description:
The wheel is cool (spin the wheel, and get the flavor it lands on) though I'm such a picky eater that I don't dare give it a try.  Having a repertoire of 500 flavors is impressive though the store carries 49 at a time.  Some are quite creative, such as Star Wars (blue vanilla ice cream with orange marshmallow stars), vegetable, and zucchini.  They have Asian flavors (e.g., ube, sesame, taro) and traditional flavors (e.g., kookie dough, mocha chip, vanilla rocky road).  They're also open to suggestions for new ice cream flavors (Creme brulee?  Gingerbread?)  

I tried the red bean ice cream and Turkish coffee ice cream.  The red bean ice cream was sweet and creamy with some whole red beans but seriously lacked red bean flavor.  It was just okay.  The Turkish coffee ice cream was much better.  I'm hoping I'll come back when champagne strawberry and coffee cloves are on the menu (they should post the current flavors online).  

They have ice cream sundaes, milkshakes, floats and freezes, along with some savory snacks (even burritos).  I miss the old location - this one still looks pretty new and spiffy. Limited seating.  Prices have gone up since that picture of the menu was taken.  I think it was $4.25 for two scoops (in the picture it says $3.75).
 
If you visit their website, you'll find a coupon: http://www.pollyann.com/coupon.asp
author: Lolia S.

description:
Another San Francisco staple.

A plethora of flavors. Basics like strawberry and vanilla to exotic and complex flavors like lychee, durian, and my fav TARO! What a delicious and creamy texture and taste =). 

My advice on choosing what to get: SPIN THE WHEEL. ALWAYS SPIN THE WHEEL. Be adventurous! You might even get a free cone! I've gotten one before, yay!
author: Christine C.

description:
Note to self... DON'T get durian (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Durian) ice cream while pregnant. When I was in my first trimester, I got a random hankering for ice cream. Not just any ice cream, mind you, but ice cream from that "mystery-place-out-in-the-outer-sunset that-I-can-never-remember-the-name -of and-have-no-idea-how-to-find even-though-I've-been-there-3-times" spot. 

So, Mr. B and I cruised around the outer sunset doing large loops of various blocks of on-and-on identical type housing with nary a glimpse of the place. We were on both sides of Sunset Boulevard, and then all the way to the ocean and back. It was getting late. He thought I'd officially lost it in being pregnant and was merely humoring me by letting me keep looking for it... After 20 minutes, it became a QUEST and, in my mind, this mystery ice cream place was THE VALHALLA of ice creameries. Screw Mitchells and its long lines. I was gonna get me come mystery ice cream. 

After 40 minutes, we finally stumbled upon Polly Ann and made our way in, exhausted in our search, like ship wreck survivors being tossed ashore. Nah. Just kidding. We walked in and ordered some ice cream, and it was DELISH. Now, it's no Herrell's (http://www.yelp.com/biz/k6ykGROMhNbpLQqcwkVzVw?hrid=Wry9_rCVaMOLD4wy6R63Vg),  but you'd kind of have to make your ice cream with pure fat to match Herrell's creaminess. 

The ice cream was great, as was the service - young clean cut kids, very friendly and polite. They will also hook you up with ice cream for your dog, if you happen to wander by with your pup. It's a great destination spot for late night ice cream if you're on the NW side of the city instead of the SE (in which case, it's obvious you should go to Mitchell's http://www.yelp.com/biz/76smcUUGRvq3k1MVPUXbnA). 

On a last minute impulse, I decided to try a taste of the durian ice cream (after polishing off my scoop of mint chip, or whatever comparatively mundane - and therefore sane - flavor I'd tried). They let you sample flavors here. The fellows behind the counter were really nice about it - the stuff STINKS to high heaven, so much so that, even though it's obviously frozen, they have to keep it especially wrapped and in a separate Tupperware container so as not to stink up the store. So, it was nice of them to go through the process of exposing themselves to the stench just to give little ole me a flavah savah of it. 

I'm a SERIOUS garlic lover and I love onions too... Yet, since I'd gotten pregnant, I just couldn't handle the mere thought of eating either. The counter-guys explained to me that durian tasted kind of like garlic and onion together... and I STILL insisted on tasting it. Let's just say that they were right, only it's like rotten garlic and onions, with some stale milk tossed in for extra blechiness. The taste lived in my mouth for, seriously, 4 days. 

Even though it was the nastiest thing I've ever eaten in my life, I LOVE that Polly Ann offers it and, now, not pregnant, I'm curious to try it just one more time (glutton for punishment), just to see if it tastes different without all the hormones in my body rejecting it. 

So, if you have a hankering for getting ice cream for your dog, this is the place to go. If you want some late-night ice cream, this is the spot.  If you love durian, you'd better camp outside and get it while you can (I think it's only a seasonal flavor that they carry). Enjoy!
author: Hannah Q.

description: Polly Ann has the most unique and greatest variety of flavors of all the ice cream shops that I know of in the Outer Sunset. Their rich ice cream is served in a respectable size and I can really feel it weighing me down after consumption. On this visit, I tried their aptly named Foglifter coffee/espresso ice cream. The place, not to forget to mention the old plaques Polly Ann saved from their previous location, brings back a lot of nostalgic memories of buying unhealthy snacks and candies from when I was attending the nearby middle school.
author: Cliff W.

description: I haven't spun the wheel in years. As the years passed I have become to chicken to do so. But in all these years one thing that has never changed is the delicious ice cream. Lots of traditional and non-traditional flavors. While I still love rocky road, chocolate, etc from my childhood this is the place to come for awesome Jasmine and Green Tea ice creams.
author: Maria M.

description:
A beautiful lazy sunny Sunday like the one we had this weekend kept making me and the other half want to get ice cream. Mitchell's, we've done our drive bys' three times this month only to find out that they're  closed from January 5th to the January 25th for reconstruction purposes, so we opted for Polly Ann.

Polly Ann's is deep in the Sunset, but it's worth it.  They had so many flavors and their to go tubs were cheap! 56 oz, that's 3.5 lbs of ice cream for $6.75. I didn't get one, but I really had to control myself..  We really liked the coconut and kahlua flavors. I thought the sesame flavor was okay.. but this place is a winner. I'll be back, maybe I'll bring my future dog here for an ice cream, or maybe even my children if they behave.
author: Miss Pigg y.

description:
This used to be my go to ice cream place before I discovered Bi-Rite. One day my friend and I bought a pint of ice cream and brought it to the beach with us on that rare hot SF day. I like wheel since I'm crazy indecisive, but I think the wheel does more harm than good. That durian flavor... 

Anyway I like Polly Ann's because they have snacks and it introduced me to banana ice cream. I am now obsessed with banana ice cream, and the only person who likes it.
author: Pearl R.

description:
I used to come here for the wheel.  1 in 13 chance of free ice cream is quite tempting.

However, I realized that I'd rather pay money and get good ice cream somewhere else.  In fact, I'd rather go to Safeway.
author: Jin D.

description:
C'mon BIG MONEY!... BIG MONEY!!

Watching the wheel of  random ice creams spin is like watching our beloved classic tv game show,Wheel Of Fortune... you get really anxious and nervous as the wheel starts slowing down, not knowing what your destiny will be (for ice cream that is).  

I am super indecisive, so when you put a billion flavors of ice cream in front of me,I will just stand in front of the cashier until we both grow white hairs and our body parts start sagging. Yup.. I know... thats kinda gross. So what better way to fight aging than spinning that wheel! You just CANNOT go wrong with it.  Whatever flavor it lands on, you will have a choice of that flavor or one to the left or to the right of it. 

I've never had a bad ice cream experience at this place. GO GO GO!
author: Mishi W.

description:
I am sooooooooo nostalgic for Polly Ann. Have been there since I was a youngster of 13- that's 25 freakin' years. Love the American Beauty Rose flavor- with REAL (vs. fake?) rose  petals in the mix. 

The best part (and saddest part) is that Polly Ann is not a chain, sad because I habitate in San Diego... But it's homegrown and nuthin like ColdStone or 31 Flavors beats it...
author: Lisa W.

description:
Cool place with a GAZILLION flavors.  Indecisive?  Spin the wheel and let fate decide...hehe.  

Took my parents here when they were visiting and of course, mom got the durian.  Server went to the BACK BACK and I mean BACK BACK to get the durian ice cream.  Guess they keep it under lock and key as not to scare people with the strong aroma.  

Pretty darn tasty ice cream and fun atmosphere.
author: Jennifer H.

description: Customer service at this place is not the best. These guys serving ice cream need to take a class on "customer service" alone, period. Of all the times I've been here, I always get served by that tall, unfriendly young Asian guy who always gives this death stare and a "can I help you??" with no greet at all whatsoever. Everyday is probably a bad day for him. Poor guy! I won't be going back after today's visit. I told the guy clearly that I wanted a scoop of "T-A-R-O" and he gives me "C-A-R-A-M-E-L." He knows he made a mistake, but insisted that he did ask me twice when "C-L-E-A-R-L-Y" he did not! Quit trying to cover up your mistake, fool!!!! Someone asking for taro is waaaay off from asking for caramel. Say whaaaat???? I'm sure this isn't the first time this has happened. Anyways, ice cream flavors are alright, but there are other ice cream shops (Bi-Rite Creamery and Mitchell's Ice Cream) in San Francisco that are waaaay better with great customer service as well. Enough said!
author: Honor J.

description:
Your neighborhood ice cream shop. This is a great place to stop in for some ice cream - there are a ton of flavors.  There is enough selection that there is something for everyone. For most people, it just makes a very hard decision. They have some of the more unique Asian flavors, such as jasmine tea, taro and durian.  The ice cream tastes great. Not too creamy, not too sweet.

I also like how this place has personality. If you're too indecisive (or feeling lucky), you can spin a wheel to determine which flavor to get and even have a chance to win a free ice cream.  Always worth a stop if you're in the mood for something sweet.
author: Darin L.

description:
This store is where I lost my Teenage Rebellion virginity.

I felt so daring standing there outside my middle school, on the very edge of the sidewalk. I'd been there a couple of times before but had never dared to cross that street to the Place of No Return and Ice Cream. But today I was finally going to do it! I had the perfect excuse: "drama practice." My mother wouldn't be picking me up for an hour. That gave me ample time to walk the two blocks, purchase some delicious ice cream with money obtained from my mother (ha! foolish woman, providing the very means by which I would flout her authoritah!), return to school, sit and eat, revel in the sense of danger I felt, and then sneak back inside the building so I could say I had been there all along.

I stepped off the sidewalk, and thus began my rebellion.

I crossed the two streets (while looking both ways; I was rebelling, but I would never betray my beloved safety procedures), entered the store, climbed the little steps next to the door so I could see over the counter, prepared to order the forbidden coffee ice cream... and my mother walked in to pick up a treat for my brother and me.

My plan may not have worked, but she was so proud of my honesty ("I was chasing a ball across the street because my drama teacher threw it out the window and then I saw your hair so I came over to see you and the ball rolled down the hill so you won't be able to find it but that's what happened and can I have some ice cream?") that she let me get coffee ice cream. D'aww.

So yeah, I have fond memories of the place. When I was really little my dad would walk me up the street from our house, buy us both ice cream (I'd always get chocolate chip, he'd get turkish coffee and pretend not to notice when I stole a bite), and then carry me home once the post-ice cream bliss set in.

Minus a star for the new location. I miss the dingy hole-in-the-wall. It may have been cramped and dirty, but you know what? It was home! Sort of. Well, not really, but you get the point.

And it had stairs for little people.

I miss those stairs. ):
author: Liz A.

description:
This place is definitely closer to 4 1/2 stars, but since thats not allowed, 4 will have to do.  

Ive been here only once, but i will definitely be a regular at this place! 

They score major major points for their unique selection of ice creams, including and especially their wheel.  If you don't know what flavor you want, you can spin the wheel and it will pick a flavor for you.  
I went here with my gf and one of my friends and between the three of us we tried about 5 flavors....and let me say....they were all really good :-D 

By far the part of place that sent it over the top for me, was their wide selection of flavors.  More specifically, they have all the traditional american classics like vanilla, chocolate, and peanut butter cup, but they also have unique choices like taro, lychee, and even a ginger one that i am clearly not brave enough to try lol  Oh and best part about that, is that you can literally go into this place and ask to try several of their flavors before you purchase one.  I know between the three of my us who went, we definitely tried a handful of their flavors.  So don't be afraid to ask for a sample when you can't make up your mind! :-)

If your filipino, their macapuno ice cream i thought was pretty good.  I personally like the kinds of macapuno that has chunks of its different ingredients...this place doesn't have those fun chunks, but the flavor was very much right on.

I did deduct about half a star because of their lack of seating.  We came here during that time a month or so ago when the rain wasn't letting up because of a huge craving for ice cream, and it was definitely hard to eat ice cream standing up, while huddled inside their establishment lol.  

Anyway the point is, no matter what your in the mood for, this is the ice cream shop for you! A definite place to get ice cream if your ever in the SF area! :-D
author: Mark R.

description:
Took my son for ice cream. His ice cream scoop fell off the cone, and landed on the floor. I asked the gal if he could have another one, and the gal replied, "Our policy is, once you touch the cone, it's not our responsiblity anymore". 

I later found out my sons class went here for a field trip and several kids' ice cream scoops fell off the cone and landed on the floor.  And, that same response was told as well, "Our policy is, once you touch the cone, it's not our responsibility anymore".  

The teacher insisted it was the fault of the scooper for not pushing the cone down.  Customer service is a dying breed.
author: Michelle D.

description: Best lychee ice cream in the world. Be daring and spin the wheel if you can't decide on a flavor to order. I hit this place everytime I'm in the Bay Area. Drive around the block for street parking.
author: Henry T.

description: Mitchells is waaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaay better.
author: Gwynnie P.

description:
Yummy... great job on the remodeling!  

Love that they have the most unusual, never-would-have-suspected-that-in-ice-cream flavors.  My favorites are Honeydew, Jasmine Green Tea (so fragrant!), black sesame (but Marco Polo's is better), ube and avocado.  Absolute coolness.  

Gripes?  Cash only, no real place to sit, too many bratty kids (AP Giannini Middle School is less than two blocks away).
author: Catherine C.

description:
They have the best Asian flavor ice creams, awesome banana splits, and tasty soft serve frosties (almost on par with McDonald's...almost). I drive by this ice cream parlor everyday when I leave and return home.  Everytime I have to remind myself I CAN'T have any, because I'm working out.  One cone equals 30 minutes on the treadmill!

I hate you Ms. Polly Ann, you are a temptress. Leave me alone.

TIP:  $1 off pre-packaged 1/2 gallons and quarts on Tuesdays.  They're good to bring for dinner parties.
author: Ezduzit S.

description:
Horrible.  The original owner (years ago) had much better tasting ice cream.  I know a girl who used to work there the (at that time) new owners and she had some bad things to say about the place from the inside.

Today my wife and I got the worst milk shakes from there.  My Kahlua shake barely tasted like the real thing and my wife said if she closed her eyes, she could not tell if her shake was actually strawberry or not.  Very watery.  Have these folks EVER had a GOOD milkshake from someplace else and realized what it should be like??

I'll never go there again, and I gave them a chance for nostalgic reasons since I grew up in that area.
author: Alvin A.

description:
Great icecream.. i was coming here back in the olden days when it was in the location a couple of stores down. The long narrow ice cream store. And i do remember trying the wheel and getting some weird flavor and having green poo... yeah yuck... 

still have a lot of flavors, ice cream is good, much more accessible to me than Mitchells, which is probably in my top 3 ice cream places, but not out that way too much and parking is horrible, but anyways back to polly anns... Only 4 stars cause as i do like their icecream everytime i go in the service is not so well... just seems no one behind the counter is very happy to be there and i dont like that they vary there flavors so much. At times they have this flavor go back a week later and its not there and they dont know when it will be.... sucks esp. when you were looking forward to it throughout the week.... other than that good solid icecream...
author: Shelley N.

description:
Let me be up front about this; I can't really eat ice cream. My teeth dont handle the coldness very well and as a result i eat slowly and it all melts. 

The icecream makes me over come that problem and devour with my teeth hurting and sliding into forzen numbness.

Of particular interest in this place is the variety of flavors that they offer. I recall getting a peppermint one with bits of candy cane in it.  Mango strawberry is yummy. And Bummpy Freeway is a must for anybody who likes rocky road but with bigger nuts.
author: Brian Y.

description:
So many flavors, so little stomach room. I had the lemon ripple the other day and although the counter girl was sweet enough to load on as much ice cream as the poor puny plain cone could hold, my excitement was tempered somewhat when I found a two inch long hair in my handheld sweet treat. 

The mango milkshake is tasty, though.
author: Nathalie L.

description:
Had a lick and wanted more... being that i really can't eat ice cream doesnt mean i can't taste it.  the coconut was delish.  they have a great big spinning wheel if you cant make up your mind on what kind of awesome flavor you want.. let them choose for you.  

if you are just standing around like i am, you can be entertained by the signs of wisdom and humor.
author: Lety M.

description:
SO good. How good is SO good? my friends and I went to three different supermarkets to find styrofoam containers, loaded them up with ice, went to yet another store to buy some packaging tape, all to transport a couple pints of ice cream from San Francisco to San Diego. P.S. Don't try this at home, kids. It makes for really crap refrozen ice cream.

They get four stars only because their normal offerings (the chocolate, strawberry, vanilla, so forth and so on) are really unimpressive. The special polly-ann flavors, on the other hand, are so good they make grown men giggle. Really. I've seen it. If they could just hand me a spoon and let me hop on over to the other side of that counter, I'd be the the happiest girl in the world.

Honestly, my review is going to be pretty useless. Yes, the green tea's so good lalala omg they have durian. (Side note: my roommate ordered the durian and we made her eat that bowl of stink outside. We also got her a separate styrofoam container.)

I just wanted to throw in my vote for Jasmine Green Tea ice cream. YUUMMM. I took home all the jasmine green tea ice cream they had that day, and then came back the next day to collect whatever else they could scrounge up. I don't mess around.
author: Gin K.

description:
I love the names and the many flavors beyond vanilla.  I also love how they're prepared for indecisive people like me: there's a wheel of flavors to spin; whatever it lands on, you've got to take it or the two around it.  

They also continously change their flavors.  It's good to have variety, but bad because a favorite flavor disappears quickly. I became obsessed with 3 ninjas when I first came here on a trip.  By the time I moved here, it was gone. Boo.
author: Yan E.

description:
